properties.name: Camp Carolina
properties.description: Posted by Tommylambs creek road, brevard, north carolinaSpent seven summers here as a camper and counseler. I learned to rock climb, mountain bike, kayak and canoe, play lacrosse. Also got a nasty scar from mudsliding. Good times.

properties.name: First home - 230 Callaway Drive
properties.description: Posted by Tommy230 Callaway Drive, macon, georgiaThis is the home I lived in until I was 4

properties.name: Hotel Harbor View
properties.description: Posted by Tommy Harbor View Circle, Charleston, South CarolinaI closed out the 90s living with a rotating cast of characters -- friends from Charleston and UGA -- in this glorious raised four-bedroom pad on the marsh. Goya, a striking, yellow-eyed, red and white pit bull, came into my life around this time and busied herself with stalking marsh bunnies. I began my time in Charleston living downtown with a guy whose acquaintance with teenaged skinheads necessitated an immediate roommate change and I wound up living downtown with a botanist for a few months before landing at the Hotel Harbor View. The Post and Courier was my first job out of college and, as it entailed writing a ton of obits, it epitomized dues paying in journalism. After two years of failing to convince the editors that I was the next Gay Talese, I took off for Wilmington, NC. If I\'d been earning a little more than 00/week pre-tax, Charleston probably would have been the most I\'ve ever enjoyed a city. At least until I got to Austin.

properties.name: Keble College, Oxford
properties.description: Posted by TommyOxford, United KingdomThe spring of 1995 was my first go-round as a benficiary of one of the University of Georgia\'s adventures in overseas real estate speculation under the guise of study abroad. In a rare case of actually applying myself as an undergrad (thus resulting in my most lucid memories of this period of my life), I studied existentialism and 18th century British lit under real, no foolin\' Oxford dons. There\'s a lot that\'s different about the Oxford experience from any studies in the US, but class sizes jump out as one of the most significant: one don and two students is a packed class at Keble. So it\'s not as if you can hide behind the football player if you didn\'t do the reading or gamble that the prof will call on one of the other 300 people in the stadium-sized classroom. It\'s just you, the prof, maybe one other bloke and, hopefully, the umpteen pages of very in-depth thesis you wrote on Middlemarch, the 800 pages of which you only had a week to read and research. And which I attempted to do while squeezing in my first trip to Amsterdam (I swear, I was only there to see the Rembrandt and Van Gogh museums). Also, each class meets once a week. So during that hour or two that you share with the don, you need to be on. Like Donkey Kong.

properties.name: Mempho
properties.description: Posted by Tommy101 North Rembert Street, Memphis, TennesseeOnce again after hitting my head on a very low professional ceiling (and on the heels of a crushing breakup of junior high emotional proportions), I relocated to Memphis, which I took to a hell of a lot better than I expected. Being landlocked and located in the Volunteer state, Memphis did not initially inspire confidence. It took a plate of Rendezvous ribs to obliterate my biases and I went on to join a dozen-odd other barbecue aficionados as a member of Pigs In Zen, which competed annually in the Memphis in May World Championship of Barbecue. Graham Parker once sang, "Don\'t bother with the local girls," but I didn\'t listen and went ahead and bothered. For once, it paid off. Memphis is where I met Jamie, who, eight days from the time of this writing, will be my wife. She and I were volunteering with Mpact Memphis, a non-profit I helped launch with some friends. I covered banking and finance at the Memphis Business Journal and coached up a Woodland Presbyterian\'s middle school lacrosse team from ragtags who couldn\'t throw and catch in year one to a real problem for the established private school teams in year three.

properties.name: Oak Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Tommy2110 Oak Avenue, Columbus, GeorgiaLived here from 1986 until leaving for college in 1993. My parents stayed here through 2002. The house was built in 1915 as an Episcopal rectory and had a massive backyard that was the default location for every backyard football game in midtown Columbus. I attended Columbus High during this period, began a lifelong hobby of distance running and left a couple of gallons of sweat on the turf at Blue Hell, home of the CHS soccer team. I also played guitar -- badly -- for Maken Melodye (Chaucerian English for "fuck" -- ah, high school) with Cameron Lane, Erin Wamble, Dan Floyd and Tommy Tjoflat (later replaced by Colby Cardin). It was like the Summer of \'69 except nobody got married. Notwithstanding a few decent Velvet Underground covers and a few decent originals ("The Charleston Song" and "Fishman," I believe, were titles), we just, frankly, weren\'t very good and were forced to concede the issue after a disastrously bad gig at a friend\'s lakehouse. During the summer of \'94 I made a second run at the \'Bus\' not-exactly-burgeoning music scene as lead (and I use that word loosely) guitarist for Radio Speed, which included Jon Lumpkin, Pat Knopf and Dan. Experience and alcohol calmed our nerves and we bashed out semi-competent covers of Neil Young, Johnny Thunders, the New York Dolls, T. Rex, the Ramones, the Sex Pistols, Pavement and Elvis Costello before a mostly appreciative audience at the Human Experience Theatre downtown as the opener for local heroes East Orange. I am the source of a rare instance of a guitar solo being played in a Ramones song, which was necessitated by Jon leaving the mic to have words with a skinhead who\'d nearly electrocuted him by skanking into the mic and inadvertently slamming it into Jon\'s teeth.

properties.name: Parma
properties.description: Posted by TommyStrada Giovanni Cavestro, 43100 Parma PR, ItalyI finished up undergrad in style, with this epicurean adventure in the home of Parma ham (aka prosciutto), parmasan cheese and the infamous Parmalat. This study abroad trip was ostensibly centered on classes in magazine article writing and critical writing, but it was also liberally dosed with trips to the Italian and French rivieras, Rome, Milan and followed by a pan-European trek through Copenhagen, Netherlands, Prague, Munich, Switzerland, Chamonix and Paris. We saw "Aida" in a Roman coliseum and got drunk with the cast afterwards. After the program was over, I bungee-jumped from a cable car in Interlachen, Switzerland at midnight, from one of the world\'s highest drops, hiked across the Mer du Glace glacier near Chamonix and Mont Blanc, and ice-climbed and rock-climbed. Yes, this was an excessive way of knocking out my last two credits in J-school, but, for reasons I hope are obvious to the reader, I regret very little about it.

properties.name: Phi Delta Theta - Georgia Alpha Chapter (1995)
properties.description: Posted by Tommy690 South Lumpkin Street, Athens, GeorgiaDue to a combination of alcohol-driven memory loss and legal concerns, I can\'t divulge specifics on this one. We had long hair and an affinity for firearms and for tossing furniture and appliances from high places. In the eyes of the UGA greek system, the campus at large and, most acutely, the administration, we were black sheep. Or maybe just morons. I can\'t remember anyone giving it much thought at the time. Eventually, 40 of us got the boot. But, by then, we were seniors and most of the damage had been done. Emphasis on "most."

properties.name: Rai Leh Bay
properties.description: Posted by TommyJamie and I got engaged here on March 21, 2005, in a mostly well-executed plan on my part. There had been some gnashing of teeth about when I would do what Jamie and all of her friends were long tired of waiting for me to do. Unbeknownst to me and well-knowst to everyone else, the one-year mark in Austin was my deadline, which I ... uh, missed. Bu-bu-but, I had a plan. Following a study abroad trip in Southeast Asia, I would fly Jamie out to Thailand for a week, whereupon I would bust out the hardware. (Ok, so I had to sell my car to finance the excursion, leaving me car-less ever since. All that makes me is one less dumbass paying .50 a gallon.) So Jamie makes it to Bangkok, which was sort of a surprise to both of us. I mean, dating for three years is a strong statement and so is moving from Memphis to Austin (although not as strong as moving to Texarkana, but, until such time as I have the incredible misfortune of having to put that fair burg on my map, we\'ll let that one go). But boarding a plane for 20 hours to fly to a third-world Sin City that\'s more sinful than Amsterdam and Vegas combined, well, that\'s put-up-or-shut-up-type stuff. So Jamie arrives and the next day we\'re off to Rai Leh Bay to tour some temples, paddle kayaks along the Andaman coast and get our backs massaged into butter. I guess it was day 2 and my master plan was a day of paddling and snorkling before making our way over to a small island, Chicken Island, and propose at Sunset. Problem was, Jamie had an unforeseen aversion to open water paddling. Granted, this was open water paddling over an area that never got much deeper than two feet. But it was open water and after a few ridiculous minutes of me angrily paddling forward while she frantically paddled backward, I let it go. Try to picture the emotional arc here: a level of anxiety that wouldn\'t be out of place on one\'s first attempt at skydiving, followed by vein-bulging aggravation, followed by some serious resignation, as in, a family of black cats just crossed your path on Friday the 13th while you, glimpsing through your broken rear-view mirror, spot a mockingbird drop dead out of a tree. So yeah, I was feeling some pensiveness. Eventually, we found a secluded beach with a nice view of the setting sun and I stammered my way through a speech that, inexplicably, I had never gotten around to rehearsing. ("So you made this big jump to Austin with me and then leapt across the Pacific to join me here and, hey, speaking of leaps ..." I have no idea what I actually said, but it was probably about that awful.) In spite of all that, she accepted. Clearly, I wouldn\'t be telling you otherwise.

properties.name: San Fran
properties.description: Posted by Tommy2269 Francisco Street, San Francisco, CaliforniaThe summer of 2004 was something of a Casbah reunion, as I lived with Jed and his eventual bride, Hilarie Silvers. I was interning with the Independent Online Distribution Alliance, a digital music distributor. Jed and I made the most of our free time by climbing Mount Tamalpais and Half Dome at Yosemite. I also spent a week living with Jed\'s incredibly hospitable former roommates, Ron Mori and Jen Krook.

properties.name: South Milledge 1995-1997
properties.description: Posted by Tommy1655 South Milledge Avenue, Athens, Georgia"When the going gets weird, the weird turn pro." - Raul Duke Older but not wiser, Jed, Jay and I decamped here to the Casbah in the fall of 1995. After the setback at Phi Delt, this became home base to the Navajo Nation and the Four Horsemen, who counted coup in SEC locales such as Columbia, Lexington, Starkville and Jacksonville. Jay bought the Bop Gun and a nervous pit bull named Seven who, at my urging, became convinced that a nation of cats lived underground on our property. Gradually, other pit bull owners brought their dogs to our place and God knows how many traffic accidents were nearly caused by people staring at the dogs taking turns hanging by their jaws on a three-inch thick rope hanging from a tree in the front yard.

properties.name: St. Simons
properties.description: Posted by Tommybruce drive, st. simons island, georgiaPretty tough to overstate the importance of this place in my life. Growing up, we spent every summer on this island at a hourse our family owned for decades called Beachwater. That was also the case for my mother, whose ashes we spread off the northern tip of East Beach. My brother and I used to go crabbing off the Sea Island pier, the East Beach Causeway and off the northern tip of Sea Island (I was going to say "catch crabs," but the fact that the nearest prostitutes to this area are in Brunswick is probably not common knowledge). If the hauls were big enough, we\'d sell some to the owner of the pier or to Gisco\'s Seafood for 5 cents apiece and boil the rest. We oftened fished off the piers as well and, at the Sea Island pier, there were a couple of sea otters, Miss Piggy and, later, Beauty, who barked and did all kinds of tricks, like swimming the backstroke, to induce us to toss them some entrails. Ben and I learned to horseback ride here as well. On our first vacation as a couple, I took Jamie down to the Georgia coast. We stayed in a primitive B\'n\'B on Sapelo Island for a few days and were regailed with plenty of Gullah and Geechee legends by Cornelia Bailey, the island\'s historian, griot and all-around matriarch. This was the first time I took Jamie sea kayaking and, due to some close encounters of the gator kind, it came damned close to being her last such experience. After reaching an impasse at a gator-filled inlet, we walked the length o the beach back to the empty mansion once inhabited by tobacco magnate and Sapelo lord R.J. Reynolds, where we were prepared to spend the night on the marble porch. Fortunately, it was too dark to see the massive cockroaches that were crawling all over it. Even more fortunately, one of the island\'s residents happened to be cruising the area in their truck and we flagged them down and got a ride back to the cottage. Their back window had a "Gators" sticker (as in the hated University of Florida football team) on the back window and we were almost too dehydrated and exhausted to note the irony.

properties.name: The 'To
properties.description: Posted by Tommy2725 Franklin Boulevard, Sacramento, CaliforniaThrough several strange twists of fate following an increasingly desperate jobless summer of 2005, I landed at Intel as a senior financial analyst in August 2005 and set up in Sacramento. Jamie, Tanner and Goya moved in in the fall. We ran the 2005 California International Marathon, our first \'thon, and planned our wedding, which was in Memphis. We lasted a little over a year in Sacto and happily moved back to Austin around Christmas 2006.

properties.name: The ATX
properties.description: Posted by Tommy1509 Dexter Street, Austin, TexasI got an MBA at the University of Texas at Austin\'s McCombs School of Business. Jamie and I got engaged during this time and, on several occasions, I nearly gorged myself on Polvo\'s chile rellenos and brisket from Johnny Mueller\'s and any of the various establishments in nearby Lockhart. We lived within walking distance of Town Lake, which helped to offset some of my consumption, and of Zilker Park, scene of the fabulous Austin City Limits music festival. Although I worked my ass off here, I\'ll confirm what should be a given: I saw an incredible amount of live music as well. Somehow, I managed to come around to the color orange, although that was helped by the Longhorns having the good taste to burn it. Memphis friends Kate and John Morton followed us down here and we became great friends with our neighbors, Brett Smith and Sam Symons. Desperately homesick, we returned around Christmas 2006 and have no plans to leave again.

properties.name: Where it all began
properties.description: Posted by Tommy380 Hospital Drive, Macon, GeorgiaI was born here at 7:57 p.m. EST April 25, 1975, delivered by Conrad P. Grossman, M.D.

properties.name: Wilmiwood
properties.description: Posted by Tommy5605 Hillwood Street, Wilmington, NCI landed here in the summer of 1999, living with Dee "Nuts" DeLoatche and Chad "The Weapon," two Carolina grads who learned from my college football appreciation and taught me plenty about college basketball. Even by my standards, it was a relatively short stay. As a reporter with the Morning Star/Star-News, I covered Brunswick County, which had the distinction of having the largest number of mobile homes of any county in North Carolina. It was a swamp-laden county sandwiched between Wilmington and Myrtle Beach that was rapidly being overtaken by litigious snowbirds from the Northeast and Midwest (fistfights among senior citizens at a sewer board meeting were not unheard of), but you could get could barbecue in Shallotte and clog your arteries with Calabash\'s namesake fried seafood. I did a lot of kayaking in the inlets around Wrightsville Beach and Masonboro, and downed a lot of beers in the same areas a few hours later. Bought my first kayak off Wrightsville Beach, a red Necky Looksha Sport, which I not so obliquely dubbed "The Red Necky."

properties.name: Woodberry Forest
properties.description: Posted by Tommy 898 Woodberry Forest Rd, Orange, VirginiaI attended boarding school here from 1989-1991. Mostly what I recall was your garden variety teen angst, amplified by the setting of an all-boys school in rural Northern Virginia. Instead of going by the US system of 9th grad, 10th grade, etc., Woodberry goes by the English system of "forms," i.e., 9th grade would be third form, and so on. No, I\'m not kidding. People wore bowties unironically. I learned to play guitar here and panted my way through soccer, wrestling and lacrosse seasons. Because there were no such things as cell phones or the Internet, I remember writing letters to girls at area boarding schools whom I\'d met at mixers arranged by our respective schools. The lameness of that last sentence almost gave me a seizure. Needless to say, two years of that was enough for me.
